name: California Condor
habitat: Rocky cliffs and open forests of California, Arizona, and Utah
description: The California Condor is the largest flying bird in North America with a wingspan of nearly 10 feet! They almost went extinct in the 1980s when only 27 were left, but thanks to breeding programs, their numbers are slowly growing.
funFacts: A California Condor's wingspan is almost as wide as a car is long!
They can soar to heights of 15,000 feet without flapping their wings.
Condors can live up to 60 years in the wild.
threats: Lead poisoning from eating animals shot with lead bullets
whatYouCanDo: Learn about condors and share what you know with friends
Support wildlife conservation organizations
Never litter, especially in natural areas

name: Red Wolf
habitat: Forests, wetlands, and coastal prairies of the southeastern United States
description: The Red Wolf is one of the rarest animals in the world. They are smaller than gray wolves but bigger than coyotes. They live only in a tiny area of North Carolina today.
funFacts: Red wolves are very shy and rarely seen by people.
They mate for life and both parents help raise the pups.
Red wolf pups are born with their eyes closed and don't open them for about two weeks.
threats: Being mistaken for coyotes by hunters
whatYouCanDo: Tell others about the red wolf so more people know they exist
Support groups that protect wolves
Write letters to leaders asking them to protect wolf habitats

name: Florida Panther
habitat: Swamps, forests, and grasslands of southern Florida
description: The Florida Panther is a type of cougar that lives only in the swamps and forests of southern Florida. They are amazing swimmers and can even cross wide rivers! There were once only about 20 left, but now there are more than 100.
funFacts: Florida Panthers can jump 15 feet in the air from a standing position!
Each panther needs a territory as large as 200 square miles.
Baby panthers have blue eyes that turn yellow as they grow up.
threats: Cars hitting them when they cross roads
Habitat loss from buildings and farms
whatYouCanDo: Ask your family to drive carefully in wildlife areas
Learn about Florida's wetlands and why they matter
Support wildlife crossings that help animals cross roads safely

name: Whooping Crane
habitat: Wetlands and marshes of North America
description: The Whooping Crane is the tallest bird in North America, standing nearly 5 feet tall! They got their name from the loud whooping call they make. In 1941, there were only 21 left, but people worked hard to save them.
funFacts: Whooping Cranes dance! They jump, bow, and flap their wings to impress each other.
They fly over 2,500 miles during migration every year.
Scientists once dressed up in crane costumes to teach baby cranes how to migrate!
whatYouCanDo: Learn about wetlands and why they are important for birds
Participate in bird counting events near your home
Keep cats indoors to protect wild birds

name: Black-footed Ferret
habitat: Grasslands and prairies of the western United States
description: The Black-footed Ferret is the only ferret native to North America. They were once thought to be completely extinct! A small group was found in 1981, and scientists worked to breed them and bring them back.
funFacts: Black-footed ferrets spend about 90% of their time underground in prairie dog burrows.
They do a funny 'war dance' where they hop sideways and arch their back when excited.
A single ferret can eat over 100 prairie dogs in one year.
threats: Loss of prairie dog colonies (their main food)
whatYouCanDo: Learn about prairie ecosystems and how all animals are connected
Support prairie conservation projects
Tell your friends about this amazing comeback story

name: Monarch Butterfly
habitat: Meadows, fields, and forests across North America
description: Monarch Butterflies are famous for their incredible migration, traveling up to 3,000 miles from Canada to Mexico every year! Their bright orange and black wings warn predators that they taste bad.
funFacts: Monarchs can travel up to 100 miles in a single day during migration!
They taste with their feet, not their mouths.
It takes four generations of monarchs to complete one full migration cycle.
threats: Loss of milkweed plants where they lay eggs
whatYouCanDo: Plant milkweed and wildflowers in your garden
Avoid using pesticides on your lawn
Create a butterfly garden at your school

name: North Atlantic Right Whale
habitat: Atlantic Ocean along the eastern coast of North America
description: The North Atlantic Right Whale is one of the most endangered large whales in the world. They got their name because whalers thought they were the 'right' whale to hunt. Today, only about 350 are left.
funFacts: Each right whale can be identified by the unique pattern of rough patches on their head.
They can weigh up to 70 tons, which is as heavy as about 10 elephants!
Mother right whales whisper to their calves to avoid attracting predators.
threats: Climate change warming their ocean habitat
whatYouCanDo: Reduce, reuse, recycle to keep oceans clean
Learn about ocean conservation
Support rules that make ships slow down to protect whales

name: Scarlet Macaw
habitat: Tropical rainforests from Mexico to Central and South America
description: The Scarlet Macaw is one of the most colorful birds in the world, with bright red, yellow, and blue feathers. They are very smart and can learn to mimic words. They live in the rainforests of Central and South America.
funFacts: Scarlet Macaws can live up to 75 years in captivity!
They eat clay from riverbanks to help digest the toxins in unripe fruits.
Macaw couples hold hands (or rather, claws) and groom each other.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy a wild-caught parrot as a pet
Support rainforest conservation groups
Choose products that are rainforest-friendly

name: Hawksbill Sea Turtle
habitat: Coral reefs and coastal waters of tropical oceans
description: Hawksbill Sea Turtles have a beautiful shell with overlapping plates and a pointed beak that looks like a hawk's bill. They are very important for coral reefs because they eat sponges that would otherwise crowd out the coral.
funFacts: Hawksbill turtles can hold their breath for up to 5 hours while sleeping!
They have been around for over 100 million years, since the time of the dinosaurs.
A single hawksbill can eat over 1,000 pounds of sponges in a year.
threats: Being hunted for their beautiful shells
whatYouCanDo: Never buy anything made from turtle shell
Reduce plastic use, especially straws and bags
If you visit a beach, turn off lights at night during nesting season

name: Resplendent Quetzal
habitat: Cloud forests of Central America
description: The Resplendent Quetzal is one of the most beautiful birds on Earth. Males have shimmering green feathers and tail feathers that can be 3 feet long! Ancient Mayan and Aztec people thought they were sacred.
funFacts: The Quetzal is the national bird of Guatemala, and their money is even named after it!
Ancient Aztecs and Mayans believed the quetzal was a god of the air.
Male quetzals grow new tail feathers every year during mating season.
threats: Illegal capture for the pet trade
whatYouCanDo: Learn about cloud forests and why they are special
Support conservation projects in Central America
Share quetzal facts with your friends and family

name: Axolotl
habitat: Lake Xochimilco in Mexico City, Mexico
description: The Axolotl is a super cool salamander that never grows up! Unlike other salamanders, it stays in its baby form its whole life and keeps its feathery gills. It can also regrow lost body parts, like legs and even parts of its brain!
funFacts: Axolotls can regrow their legs, tail, heart, and even parts of their brain!
They always look like they are smiling because of the shape of their mouth.
Axolotls come in many colors including pink, white, gold, and black.
threats: Habitat loss from Mexico City's growth
whatYouCanDo: Learn about amphibians and why clean water matters
Never release pet axolotls into the wild
Support groups working to clean up Lake Xochimilco

name: Jaguar
habitat: Tropical rainforests, swamps, and grasslands from Mexico to Argentina
description: The Jaguar is the biggest cat in the Americas and the third-largest cat in the world. Unlike most cats, jaguars love to swim! Their powerful jaws can bite through turtle shells and even crocodile skulls.
funFacts: Jaguars have the strongest bite of any big cat, even stronger than lions and tigers!
Some jaguars are all black and are sometimes called black panthers.
The name 'jaguar' comes from a Native American word meaning 'he who kills with one leap.'
threats: Being hunted by ranchers protecting livestock
whatYouCanDo: Support rainforest conservation
Choose products that don't harm rainforests
Learn about jaguars and share what you know

name: Baird's Tapir
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests of Central America and Mexico
description: Baird's Tapir is the largest land mammal in Central America. It has a funny wiggly nose that works like a short trunk! Tapirs are actually related to horses and rhinos, even though they look more like pigs.
funFacts: Tapirs use their flexible snout like a snorkel when swimming underwater!
Baby tapirs have stripes and spots that help them hide in the forest, like a watermelon pattern.
Tapirs have existed for over 55 million years and have barely changed!
whatYouCanDo: Learn about tapirs and spread the word about these amazing animals
Support Central American wildlife reserves
Choose shade-grown coffee that protects forests

name: Golden Lion Tamarin
habitat: Atlantic coastal forests of Brazil
description: The Golden Lion Tamarin is a tiny monkey with a magnificent golden-orange mane that looks like a lion! They live only in a small area of Brazilian rainforest. They were nearly extinct but conservation efforts have helped them come back.
funFacts: Golden Lion Tamarins are only about 10 inches tall, small enough to fit in your hand!
They sleep in tree holes at night to stay safe from predators.
Tamarin dads carry their babies on their backs most of the time.
whatYouCanDo: Support Brazilian rainforest conservation programs
Never buy wild animals as pets
Learn about the Atlantic Forest and why it matters

name: Andean Condor
habitat: Andes Mountains and Pacific coastlines of South America
description: The Andean Condor has the largest wingspan of any bird of prey and can soar over 100 miles without flapping its wings even once! It is the national bird of several South American countries and is a symbol of power and health.
funFacts: Andean Condors can soar at heights of 18,000 feet, higher than most airplanes fly!
Their wingspan can reach over 10 feet, wider than most cars.
Condors are very clean birds and spend hours grooming their feathers every day.
threats: Poisoning from eating animals killed with pesticides
whatYouCanDo: Learn about the Andes Mountains and the animals that live there
Support conservation groups in South America
Tell others about these incredible birds

name: Amazon River Dolphin
habitat: Rivers and flooded forests of the Amazon and Orinoco basins
description: The Amazon River Dolphin is the largest river dolphin in the world and can be bright pink! They live in the murky waters of the Amazon River and use echolocation to find fish. Local legends say they are magical creatures.
funFacts: Amazon River Dolphins turn pinker when they get excited!
They can turn their head 180 degrees because their neck bones are not fused together.
They use echolocation like a built-in sonar to find food in dark, muddy water.
threats: Water pollution from mining and farming
whatYouCanDo: Keep rivers clean by never throwing trash in waterways
Learn about river ecosystems
Support groups that protect the Amazon

name: Giant Otter
habitat: Rivers, lakes, and wetlands of South America
description: The Giant Otter is the longest otter in the world, growing up to 6 feet long! They live in family groups and are very noisy, making loud screams, barks, and snorts to talk to each other. They are sometimes called 'river wolves' because they hunt in packs.
funFacts: Giant otters eat up to 9 pounds of fish every single day!
Each otter has a unique throat patch, like a fingerprint, that identifies them.
Giant otter families hunt together and can even scare off caimans (a type of crocodile)!
whatYouCanDo: Keep waterways clean
Support river conservation projects
Learn about why healthy rivers are important for all animals

name: Hyacinth Macaw
habitat: Tropical forests, palm swamps, and grasslands of Brazil, Paraguay, and Bolivia
description: The Hyacinth Macaw is the largest flying parrot in the world, with brilliant cobalt-blue feathers and bright yellow patches around its eyes. They are very social and playful, and they love to hang upside down!
funFacts: Their beak is strong enough to crack a coconut!
Hyacinth Macaws can grow up to 3.3 feet long, about as tall as a toddler.
They mate for life and are always seen in pairs or family groups.
threats: Illegal trapping for the pet trade
whatYouCanDo: Never buy wild-caught birds as pets
Support anti-poaching efforts
Learn about responsible pet ownership

name: Blue Poison Dart Frog
habitat: Tropical rainforests of Suriname and northern Brazil
description: The Blue Poison Dart Frog is a tiny frog with brilliant blue skin covered in black spots. Its bright color is a warning to predators that it is poisonous! Indigenous people once used their toxins on the tips of blow darts for hunting.
funFacts: One frog has enough poison to make 10 grown men very sick!
They are only about 2 inches long but can be heard from far away.
Dart frog dads carry tadpoles on their backs to water pools high up in trees.
threats: Collection for the illegal pet trade
Climate change affecting their rainforest home
whatYouCanDo: Never take animals from the wild
Support rainforest protection
Learn about amphibians and why they are important

name: Maned Wolf
habitat: Grasslands and scrub forests of central South America
description: The Maned Wolf looks like a fox on stilts! It has super long legs that help it see over the tall grass of its habitat. Despite its name, it is not actually a wolf at all. It is the only species in its genus.
funFacts: Maned wolves' urine smells like marijuana, which confuses people near zoos!
They are omnivores and love eating a fruit called the wolf apple.
Their long legs are an adaptation for walking through tall grasslands.
threats: Being hit by cars on roads
whatYouCanDo: Learn about South American grasslands
Support wildlife conservation in Brazil
Help keep domestic pets vaccinated to prevent disease spread

name: Western Gorilla
habitat: Tropical forests of western and central Africa
description: The Western Gorilla is our closest relative after chimpanzees, sharing about 98% of our DNA! They live in family groups led by a silverback male. Despite their big size, they are gentle giants who mostly eat plants.
funFacts: Gorillas can learn sign language and communicate with humans!
Every gorilla has a unique nose print, just like your fingerprints.
Silverback males can weigh up to 400 pounds and are 10 times stronger than the strongest human.
threats: Habitat loss from logging and mining
whatYouCanDo: Recycle old cell phones, which contain minerals mined from gorilla habitats
Support gorilla conservation organizations
Learn about great apes and share their story

name: Chimpanzee
habitat: Tropical forests and savannas of western and central Africa
description: Chimpanzees are our closest living relatives, sharing about 98.7% of our DNA! They are incredibly smart and use tools like sticks to fish for termites and rocks to crack nuts. They live in large communities and have complex social lives.
funFacts: Chimps make and use over 20 different types of tools!
They laugh when they play, just like humans do.
Chimps in different areas have different cultures, like humans from different countries.
whatYouCanDo: Recycle electronics to reduce demand for mining in chimp habitats
Support chimpanzee sanctuaries
Never support entertainment that uses chimpanzees

name: African Forest Elephant
habitat: Dense tropical forests of central and western Africa
description: The African Forest Elephant is smaller than its savanna cousin but is still huge! They have straighter, thinner tusks and rounder ears. They are sometimes called the 'gardeners of the forest' because they spread seeds everywhere they walk.
funFacts: Forest elephants help fight climate change by spreading tree seeds throughout the forest!
They can communicate with rumbles so low that humans cannot hear them.
A forest elephant can eat up to 300 pounds of food per day.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy ivory products
Support anti-poaching efforts in Africa
Learn about how elephants help the environment

name: Mandrill
habitat: Tropical rainforests of central western Africa
description: The Mandrill is the most colorful mammal in the world, with a bright blue and red face and a rainbow-colored bottom! Males are especially colorful. They are the largest of all monkeys and live in huge groups called hordes.
funFacts: A mandrill horde can have up to 800 members!
The more dominant a male mandrill is, the brighter and more colorful his face becomes.
Mandrills have cheek pouches where they store food, like built-in grocery bags.
threats: Being captured for illegal pet trade
whatYouCanDo: Learn about African rainforests and their amazing animals
Support conservation groups working in central Africa
Never buy wild animals as pets

name: White-bellied Pangolin
habitat: Tropical forests of west and central Africa
description: Pangolins are the only mammals in the world covered in scales! When scared, they curl up into a tight ball that even lions cannot open. Sadly, they are the most trafficked mammals on Earth because people illegally sell their scales.
funFacts: Pangolins have tongues longer than their bodies!
They curl into a ball so tight that even a lion cannot unroll them.
A single pangolin can eat up to 70 million ants and termites per year!
threats: Illegal wildlife trade for their scales and meat
whatYouCanDo: Never buy products made from endangered animal parts
Spread awareness about pangolin trafficking
Support anti-poaching organizations

name: African Grey Parrot
habitat: Dense forests of west and central Africa
description: The African Grey Parrot is considered the smartest bird in the world! They can learn hundreds of words and even understand what they mean. Their silvery-grey feathers and bright red tail make them easy to recognize.
funFacts: An African Grey named Alex could count, identify colors, and even say 'I love you'!
They can mimic sounds perfectly, including phones ringing, doorbells, and other people's voices.
Grey parrots have been shown to have the intelligence of a 5-year-old human child.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy a wild-caught parrot
If you want a parrot, adopt from a rescue center
Tell others that wild parrots belong in the wild

name: Mountain Gorilla
habitat: Mountain forests of the Virunga volcanoes and Bwindi in central Africa
description: Mountain Gorillas live high up in the misty mountains of central Africa. They are one of the most endangered great apes, but their numbers have been growing thanks to incredible conservation work. They are gentle, family-loving animals.
funFacts: Mountain gorillas share 98% of their DNA with humans!
Baby gorillas ride on their mothers' backs until they are about 3 years old.
Each gorilla builds a new nest to sleep in every single night.
threats: Habitat loss from farming and conflict
whatYouCanDo: Support gorilla conservation programs
Learn about mountain gorillas and share their story
Recycle old cell phones to reduce mining in gorilla habitats

name: African Savanna Elephant
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and woodlands of eastern and southern Africa
description: The African Savanna Elephant is the largest land animal on Earth! They can weigh as much as a school bus. Elephants are extremely smart, have amazing memories, and even mourn their dead family members.
funFacts: An elephant's trunk has over 40,000 muscles and can pick up a single blade of grass!
Elephants are the only animals that cannot jump.
They communicate with sounds so low that humans cannot hear them, called infrasound.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy ivory products
Support elephant sanctuaries and anti-poaching programs
Tell others about why elephants are important for their ecosystem

name: Black Rhinoceros
habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and tropical bushland of eastern and southern Africa
description: The Black Rhinoceros is not actually black! It got its name to tell it apart from the White Rhino, which is not actually white either. Black rhinos have a pointed upper lip for grabbing leaves and twigs from bushes and trees.
funFacts: Rhinos have been on Earth for over 50 million years, even before humans!
Despite their size, black rhinos can run up to 35 miles per hour.
A group of rhinos is called a 'crash'!
threats: Political conflict in their range countries
whatYouCanDo: Never buy rhino horn products
Support anti-poaching organizations
Learn about rhinos and tell others why their horns should stay on their heads

name: Cheetah
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, and open woodlands of Africa
description: The Cheetah is the fastest land animal on Earth, reaching speeds up to 70 miles per hour! That is as fast as a car on a highway. They have special adaptations like semi-retractable claws that work like running spikes on shoes.
funFacts: A cheetah can go from 0 to 60 mph in just 3 seconds, faster than most sports cars!
Cheetahs cannot roar like lions, but they can purr like house cats.
The black 'tear marks' on their face help reduce sun glare when hunting.
threats: Cubs being taken for illegal pet trade
whatYouCanDo: Support cheetah conservation programs
Learn about how farmers and cheetahs can live together
Never support the illegal exotic pet trade

name: African Wild Dog
habitat: Grasslands, savannas, and open woodlands of sub-Saharan Africa
description: African Wild Dogs are one of the most successful hunters in Africa, catching their prey about 80% of the time! They have beautiful patchy fur with brown, black, and white spots. No two wild dogs have the same pattern.
funFacts: Wild dogs vote on whether to go hunting by sneezing! More sneezes means they go.
They share food with sick or injured pack members, making sure everyone eats.
Their huge round ears help them hear other pack members from miles away.
whatYouCanDo: Keep pet dogs vaccinated to prevent disease spread to wild animals
Support wildlife corridors that connect wild dog habitats
Learn about these amazing team players

name: Rothschild's Giraffe
habitat: Savannas and woodlands of Uganda and Kenya
description: Rothschild's Giraffe is one of the most endangered types of giraffe. You can tell them apart from other giraffes because they have no markings below their knees, making them look like they are wearing white stockings!
funFacts: They are the tallest animals on Earth and can grow up to 20 feet tall!
A giraffe's tongue is about 18 inches long and is purple-black to protect it from sunburn.
Giraffes only need to sleep about 30 minutes a day!
whatYouCanDo: Support giraffe conservation organizations
Learn about giraffes and why they are important
Visit accredited zoos that support giraffe conservation

name: Ethiopian Wolf
habitat: Afroalpine grasslands and heathlands of the Ethiopian highlands
description: The Ethiopian Wolf is the rarest canid in the world and Africa's most endangered carnivore. With their reddish fur and long snout, they look like a fox but are true wolves. They live only in the high mountains of Ethiopia.
funFacts: Ethiopian wolves are the rarest wolves on Earth!
They hunt alone for rodents but come together as a pack to socialize and protect territory.
They live at altitudes above 10,000 feet, higher than most other wolves.
threats: Climate change shrinking their mountain habitat
whatYouCanDo: Support vaccination programs for dogs near wolf habitats
Learn about Ethiopian wildlife
Tell others about this rare and beautiful wolf

name: Ring-tailed Lemur
habitat: Dry forests and scrublands of southern Madagascar
description: Ring-tailed Lemurs are famous for their long, black-and-white striped tails. They live only on the island of Madagascar, off the coast of Africa. They love sunbathing and sit with their arms spread wide to warm up in the morning sun!
funFacts: Lemurs have 'stink fights' where males rub smelly stuff on their tails and wave them at rivals!
Female lemurs are the bosses of the group, not the males.
Their tail has exactly 13 black and 13 white stripes.
whatYouCanDo: Support Madagascar conservation projects
Learn about why Madagascar is so special for wildlife
Never keep lemurs as pets

name: Iberian Lynx
habitat: Mediterranean forests and scrublands of Spain and Portugal
description: The Iberian Lynx is the most endangered wild cat in the world. They have beautiful spotted fur and tufts of black hair on the tips of their ears. In 2002, there were only about 100 left, but conservation efforts have brought them back to over 1,000!
funFacts: Iberian Lynx are one of the greatest conservation success stories ever!
Their ear tufts help them hear better by funneling sound into their ears.
They mainly eat rabbits and need to catch about one rabbit per day to survive.
threats: Loss of rabbit populations (their main food)
Being hit by cars on roads
whatYouCanDo: Learn about conservation success stories and share them
Support wildlife crossing projects that help animals cross roads safely
Tell others that saving species is possible

name: European Bison
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests of eastern Europe
description: The European Bison is the largest land animal in Europe! They went completely extinct in the wild in 1927, but were brought back from just 12 animals that survived in zoos. Now they roam free in forests across Europe again.
funFacts: Every European Bison alive today is descended from just 12 animals!
Despite weighing up to 2,000 pounds, they can jump 6 feet high and run 35 mph.
They were sacred animals to many ancient European cultures.
threats: Small population with low genetic diversity
whatYouCanDo: Learn about rewilding projects bringing bison back to Europe
Support forest conservation in Europe
Share the amazing comeback story of the European Bison

name: Mediterranean Monk Seal
habitat: Coastal caves and rocky shores of the Mediterranean Sea and eastern Atlantic
description: The Mediterranean Monk Seal is one of the rarest seals in the world. They hide in sea caves to have their pups because they are so shy around people. Ancient Greeks loved these seals and believed they were protected by the gods.
funFacts: Mediterranean Monk Seals were one of the first animals to be protected by law, way back in ancient Roman times!
They can hold their breath underwater for up to 15 minutes.
Monk seals got their name because their round head and brown fur reminded people of monks.
threats: Loss of coastal habitat from tourism development
whatYouCanDo: Keep beaches and oceans clean
Support marine conservation groups
Learn about the Mediterranean Sea and its animals

name: Eurasian Brown Bear
habitat: Forests, mountains, and tundra across Europe and northern Asia
description: The Eurasian Brown Bear is a close relative of the grizzly bear. They once roamed across all of Europe, but now they are found mainly in Scandinavia, the Balkans, and Russia. They are slowly being brought back to places where they had disappeared.
funFacts: Brown bears can eat up to 90 pounds of food per day before hibernation!
They hibernate for up to 6 months during winter without eating, drinking, or going to the bathroom.
Despite their size, they can run at 30 miles per hour.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about how people and bears can live together
Support bear conservation projects in Europe
Never feed wild animals

name: European Mink
habitat: River banks, marshes, and wetlands of Europe
description: The European Mink is one of Europe's most endangered mammals. They look like a small, sleek brown cat and are excellent swimmers. They have disappeared from most of their original range and now live in only a few small areas.
funFacts: European Mink can dive underwater and stay submerged for up to 2 minutes!
They always have a white patch on their upper lip, which helps identify them.
They build their dens in riverbanks, sometimes using abandoned water vole burrows.
whatYouCanDo: Never release pet animals into the wild
Support wetland conservation
Help keep waterways clean

name: Arabian Oryx
habitat: Desert and steppe areas of the Arabian Peninsula
description: The Arabian Oryx is a beautiful white antelope that lives in the desert. They went completely extinct in the wild in the 1970s, but were bred in zoos and released back into the desert. They are one of the greatest conservation success stories ever!
funFacts: Arabian Oryx were once extinct in the wild but have been brought back!
Their white coat reflects sunlight and helps them stay cool in the hot desert.
They can sense rain from far away and walk toward it to find fresh grass.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about desert ecosystems and share what you know
Support organizations that reintroduce animals to the wild
Celebrate conservation success stories

name: Persian Leopard
habitat: Mountain forests and rocky slopes of the Caucasus, Iran, and Central Asia
description: The Persian Leopard is the largest leopard subspecies in the world. They live in the rugged mountains of Iran, Afghanistan, and the Caucasus region. They are incredibly strong and can carry prey heavier than themselves up a mountain!
funFacts: Persian Leopards can drag prey three times their own weight up a cliff!
They are so secretive that scientists mainly study them using camera traps.
Each leopard's spots pattern is unique, like a human fingerprint.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about the wild places of Central Asia
Support international wildlife conservation
Share stories about these magnificent cats

name: Saiga Antelope
habitat: Semi-arid grasslands and steppes of Central Asia
description: The Saiga Antelope has one of the most unusual noses in the animal kingdom! Their big, floppy nose works like a filter, warming cold air in winter and filtering out dust in summer. They live on the grasslands of Central Asia.
funFacts: Saiga antelopes have the funniest-looking nose of any animal, like a tiny elephant trunk!
They can run up to 50 miles per hour to escape predators.
Saigas have existed since the Ice Age and once lived alongside woolly mammoths!
threats: Harsh winters and droughts from climate change
whatYouCanDo: Learn about the amazing grasslands of Central Asia
Support wildlife conservation in Kazakhstan and Mongolia
Tell others about these funny-nosed survivors

name: Markhor
habitat: Steep mountainsides and rocky cliffs of Central Asia
description: The Markhor is the national animal of Pakistan and has the most amazing corkscrew-shaped horns of any animal! They are expert mountain climbers and can walk along the narrowest ledges high up on cliff faces.
funFacts: Markhor horns can grow up to 5 feet long and twist like a giant corkscrew!
Their name means 'snake eater' in Persian, though they mainly eat grass and leaves.
They are one of the largest wild goats in the world.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about the mountain ecosystems of Central Asia
Support community conservation programs
Tell others about Pakistan's amazing national animal

name: Snow Leopard
habitat: High mountain ranges of Central and South Asia
description: The Snow Leopard is known as the 'ghost of the mountains' because they are so hard to spot in the wild. Their thick, spotted fur keeps them warm in freezing temperatures, and their long tail helps them balance on steep mountain slopes.
funFacts: Snow leopards cannot roar! They make a special sound called a 'chuff' instead.
Their tail is almost as long as their body and they wrap it around their face like a scarf to stay warm.
They can jump up to 50 feet in a single leap, the length of a school bus!
threats: Loss of prey due to hunting
whatYouCanDo: Support snow leopard conservation organizations
Learn about mountain ecosystems
Never buy products made from wild animal fur

name: Bengal Tiger
habitat: Tropical forests, mangroves, and grasslands of India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan
description: The Bengal Tiger is the most numerous tiger subspecies but is still endangered. They are powerful hunters and excellent swimmers. Every tiger has a unique stripe pattern, just like your fingerprints are unique to you!
funFacts: No two tigers have the same stripe pattern, just like human fingerprints!
Tigers are the biggest cats in the world and can weigh over 500 pounds.
A tiger's roar can be heard from 2 miles away!
threats: Poaching for their skin, bones, and body parts
Conflict with people living near forests
whatYouCanDo: Never buy products made from tiger parts
Support tiger reserves and national parks
Learn about tigers and share why they need protection

name: Indian Rhinoceros
habitat: Grasslands and riverine forests of northern India and Nepal
description: The Indian Rhinoceros looks like it is wearing a suit of armor because of its thick, folded skin! They have only one horn, unlike African rhinos which have two. They love water and spend lots of time wallowing in muddy pools.
funFacts: Their skin looks like armor plates but is actually quite sensitive to sunburn!
Indian Rhinos are excellent swimmers and can run at 34 miles per hour.
They have been around for millions of years and were once found across all of Asia.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy rhino horn products
Support rhino conservation in India and Nepal
Learn about how local communities help protect rhinos

name: Red Panda
habitat: Temperate bamboo forests of the Himalayas and southwestern China
description: The Red Panda is a small, adorable mammal with reddish-brown fur and a striped bushy tail. Despite their name, they are not closely related to Giant Pandas! They spend most of their time in trees and use their tails like a blanket when it is cold.
funFacts: Red pandas were discovered 48 years before giant pandas and were the original 'panda'!
They have a false thumb, which is actually an extended wrist bone, to help them grip bamboo.
Red pandas can eat up to 200,000 bamboo leaves in a single day!
whatYouCanDo: Support red panda conservation projects
Learn about Himalayan forests and why they matter
Choose products that do not contribute to deforestation

name: Asian Elephant
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests and grasslands of South and Southeast Asia
description: The Asian Elephant is smaller than its African cousin but is still enormous! They are extremely intelligent and have been shown to recognize themselves in mirrors. In many Asian cultures, elephants are sacred and deeply respected.
funFacts: Asian elephants can recognize themselves in a mirror, showing self-awareness!
They mourn their dead and have been seen gently touching the bones of deceased family members.
Only some male Asian elephants have tusks, while all African elephants have them.
threats: Habitat loss from farming and development
whatYouCanDo: Never ride elephants at tourist attractions
Support ethical elephant sanctuaries
Learn about human-elephant coexistence

name: Ganges River Dolphin
habitat: Rivers and tributaries of the Ganges-Brahmaputra river system in India, Bangladesh, and Nepal
description: The Ganges River Dolphin is nearly blind and uses echolocation to find fish in the murky rivers of India! They swim on their side, dragging one flipper along the river bottom to feel for food. They are one of the oldest creatures on Earth.
funFacts: Ganges River Dolphins are practically blind and find everything using sound waves!
They always swim on their side, which is unique among dolphins.
They have been swimming in India's rivers for over 30 million years.
threats: Water pollution from factories and farms
whatYouCanDo: Never throw trash or chemicals into rivers
Support clean river projects
Learn about freshwater dolphins and why clean rivers matter

name: Indian Pangolin
habitat: Forests, grasslands, and scrublands of the Indian subcontinent
description: The Indian Pangolin looks like a walking pine cone! It is covered in tough, overlapping scales made of keratin, the same stuff your fingernails are made of. When threatened, it rolls into a perfect ball that is almost impossible to open.
funFacts: Pangolin scales are made of keratin, the same material as your fingernails!
They have no teeth and use a tongue that can be longer than their entire body to eat ants.
A mother pangolin carries her baby on her tail!
threats: Illegal trafficking for scales and meat
whatYouCanDo: Never buy pangolin products
Support anti-trafficking efforts
Spread awareness about the most trafficked mammal on Earth

name: Bornean Orangutan
habitat: Tropical and subtropical rainforests of Borneo
description: Orangutans are the largest tree-dwelling animals in the world. They are incredibly smart and use tools, build sleeping nests, and even make umbrellas from leaves when it rains! Their name means 'person of the forest' in Malay.
funFacts: Orangutans share about 97% of their DNA with humans!
They make a new sleeping nest in the trees every single night, sometimes with a pillow and blanket of leaves.
Orangutans use large leaves as umbrellas and gloves!
threats: Palm oil plantations replacing their forests
whatYouCanDo: Look for products that use sustainable palm oil
Never support having orangutans as pets
Support rainforest conservation in Borneo

name: Sumatran Rhinoceros
habitat: Dense tropical forests of Sumatra and Borneo
description: The Sumatran Rhinoceros is the smallest and hairiest rhino in the world! They are covered in reddish-brown hair and are the last surviving relatives of the woolly rhinoceros from the Ice Age. Fewer than 80 are left in the wild.
funFacts: Sumatran Rhinos are covered in hair, making them the fuzziest rhinos!
They are the closest living relatives of the extinct woolly rhinoceros.
They have been on Earth for over 15 million years!
whatYouCanDo: Never buy rhino horn products
Support Sumatran rhino conservation programs
Learn about critically endangered species and share their stories

name: Malayan Tiger
habitat: Tropical forests of the Malay Peninsula
description: The Malayan Tiger is one of the smallest tiger subspecies and lives only in the forests of Malaysia. It is the national animal of Malaysia and appears on their coat of arms. Sadly, fewer than 150 are left in the wild.
funFacts: The Malayan Tiger is the national animal of Malaysia and appears on their money!
They are excellent swimmers and love cooling off in rivers and streams.
Each tiger needs about 100 square miles of forest to live in.
threats: Deforestation for palm oil and rubber plantations
whatYouCanDo: Choose products with sustainable palm oil
Support anti-poaching patrols in Malaysia
Learn about all the different tiger subspecies

name: Proboscis Monkey
habitat: Mangrove forests, riverine forests, and swamps of Borneo
description: The Proboscis Monkey has the funniest nose in the animal kingdom! Males have a huge, floppy nose that hangs down over their mouth. Scientists think the bigger the nose, the more attractive the monkey is to females. They are also amazing swimmers!
funFacts: Male proboscis monkeys have noses so big that they have to push them aside to eat!
They are one of the best swimmers of all primates and can swim underwater.
Their big bellies are full of bacteria that help them digest leaves, like a cow's stomach.
threats: Deforestation of mangrove and riverine forests
whatYouCanDo: Support mangrove forest conservation
Learn about Borneo's unique wildlife
Choose products that do not harm rainforests

name: Komodo Dragon
habitat: Tropical savanna forests on a few small Indonesian islands
description: The Komodo Dragon is the largest lizard in the world, growing up to 10 feet long! They live on just a few small islands in Indonesia. Despite their name, they are not actually dragons, but they are just as fearsome with their venomous bite and powerful tail.
funFacts: Komodo Dragons can eat up to 80% of their body weight in one meal!
They can smell prey from nearly 6 miles away using their forked tongue.
Baby Komodo Dragons live in trees for the first few years of their life to avoid being eaten by adults!
threats: Climate change and rising sea levels
whatYouCanDo: Support Komodo National Park conservation
Learn about reptiles and why they matter
Help fight climate change by reducing energy use

name: Philippine Eagle
habitat: Tropical rainforests of the Philippines
description: The Philippine Eagle is one of the largest and most powerful eagles in the world. It is the national bird of the Philippines and is sometimes called the 'monkey-eating eagle.' With its spiky brown crest of feathers, it looks like it has a lion's mane!
funFacts: Philippine Eagles mate for life and raise only one chick every two years.
They have bright blue-grey eyes and a wild crown of feathers.
Killing a Philippine Eagle is punishable by 12 years in prison in the Philippines!
whatYouCanDo: Support Philippine Eagle Foundation
Learn about the Philippines' incredible biodiversity
Help protect forests by choosing sustainable products

name: Giant Panda
habitat: Mountain bamboo forests of central China
description: The Giant Panda is one of the most beloved animals in the world with its black and white fur and round face. They spend up to 14 hours a day eating bamboo! Thanks to conservation efforts, their numbers have been increasing.
funFacts: Pandas eat for about 14 hours every day and can munch through 38 pounds of bamboo!
Baby pandas are tiny when born, weighing only about 4 ounces, the size of a stick of butter.
Despite being classified as carnivores, 99% of their diet is bamboo.
whatYouCanDo: Support panda conservation programs in China
Learn about bamboo forests and why they matter
Celebrate this conservation success story and inspire others

name: Chinese Pangolin
habitat: Subtropical and deciduous forests of southern China and Southeast Asia
description: The Chinese Pangolin is one of the most trafficked animals on Earth. These shy, nocturnal creatures are covered in tough scales and curl into a ball when scared. They use their incredibly long, sticky tongues to slurp up ants and termites.
funFacts: A Chinese Pangolin's tongue can be longer than its entire body!
When walking, they curl their front claws under and walk on their knuckles.
Baby pangolins ride on their mother's tail like a little backpack.
threats: Traditional medicine demand for their scales
whatYouCanDo: Never buy products made from pangolin scales
Support anti-trafficking organizations
Help raise awareness about the plight of pangolins

name: Amur Leopard
habitat: Temperate forests of the Russian Far East and northeast China
description: The Amur Leopard is the rarest big cat in the world! They live in the snowy forests of far eastern Russia and China. Their thick, beautiful fur keeps them warm in freezing temperatures as low as minus 30 degrees.
funFacts: Amur Leopards can run at speeds up to 37 miles per hour!
They can leap more than 19 feet horizontally and 10 feet straight up.
Their fur grows up to 3 inches long in winter to keep them warm in the freezing cold.
threats: Habitat loss from logging and fires
Very small population with low genetic diversity
whatYouCanDo: Support Amur leopard conservation programs in Russia
Never buy products made from wild cat fur
Tell others about the rarest big cat in the world

name: Red-crowned Crane
habitat: Wetlands and marshes of Japan, China, and the Korean Peninsula
description: The Red-crowned Crane is one of the rarest cranes in the world and a symbol of luck and long life in Japan. They perform one of the most beautiful dances in the animal kingdom, bowing, jumping, and calling to each other.
funFacts: In Japan, cranes are symbols of peace, luck, and living a long life.
Red-crowned Cranes dance together in beautiful, synchronized dances.
They mate for life and can live to be 70 years old in captivity!
whatYouCanDo: Learn about wetlands and why they are important
Support wetland conservation projects
Make origami cranes to raise awareness about crane conservation

name: Yangtze Finless Porpoise
habitat: Middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River in China
description: The Yangtze Finless Porpoise is the only porpoise that lives entirely in freshwater. They have a rounded face that looks like they are always smiling! They are the last surviving cetacean in the Yangtze River after the river dolphin went extinct.
funFacts: They are known as the 'smiling angel of the Yangtze' because they always look happy!
Mothers carry their babies on their backs when swimming.
They are the only surviving freshwater cetacean in China after the Baiji dolphin went extinct.
threats: Ship traffic in the busy Yangtze River
whatYouCanDo: Learn about river conservation
Support efforts to clean up polluted rivers
Tell others about this smiling porpoise and why it needs our help

name: South China Tiger
habitat: Forests and mountains of southern China (functionally extinct in wild)
description: The South China Tiger is considered the most critically endangered tiger subspecies in the world. None have been seen in the wild for over 25 years! About 150 survive in zoos, and there are plans to someday release them back into the wild.
funFacts: The South China Tiger is considered the 'stem' tiger from which all other tiger subspecies evolved.
It is one of the smallest tiger subspecies.
Conservation programs are trying to teach captive-bred tigers how to hunt so they can return to the wild.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about all tiger subspecies and their different challenges
Support captive breeding programs
Tell others about how important it is to act before it is too late

name: Kakapo
habitat: Predator-free islands off the coast of New Zealand
description: The Kakapo is the world's heaviest parrot and the only one that cannot fly! They are also nocturnal, which is very unusual for parrots. Every single kakapo has a name, and scientists know each one personally.
funFacts: Kakapos smell really nice, like honey and flowers!
Males make a booming sound that can be heard from 3 miles away to attract females.
Every single kakapo alive has been given a name by scientists!
threats: Introduced predators like cats, rats, and stoats
whatYouCanDo: Support New Zealand's predator-free conservation efforts
Learn about island conservation and invasive species
Keep pet cats indoors to protect wild birds

name: Tasmanian Devil
habitat: Forests and coastal scrublands of Tasmania, Australia
description: The Tasmanian Devil is the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world. Despite their scary name, they are usually shy. They got their name from early European settlers who were frightened by their loud, scary screams at night!
funFacts: Tasmanian Devils have the strongest bite for their size of any mammal on Earth!
They can eat up to 40% of their body weight in just 30 minutes.
Baby devils are called 'imps' and are only the size of a grain of rice when born!
whatYouCanDo: Support Tasmanian Devil disease research
Learn about marsupials and why Australia's wildlife is so special
Drive carefully in wildlife areas when visiting Tasmania

name: Koala
habitat: Eucalyptus forests and woodlands of eastern Australia
description: Koalas are cuddly-looking marsupials that spend most of their life in eucalyptus trees. They sleep up to 22 hours a day because eucalyptus leaves give them very little energy! Despite being called koala 'bears,' they are not bears at all.
funFacts: Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day!
They have fingerprints that are almost identical to human fingerprints.
Baby koalas are called 'joeys' and ride in their mother's pouch for about 6 months.
whatYouCanDo: Support Australian wildlife organizations especially after bushfires
Learn about how climate change makes bushfires worse
Help plant trees in Australia

name: Platypus
habitat: Rivers, streams, and lakes of eastern Australia
description: The Platypus is one of the strangest animals on Earth! It has a duck bill, beaver tail, and otter feet. It is one of only two mammals that lay eggs. Males even have venomous spurs on their hind legs!
funFacts: When scientists first saw a platypus specimen, they thought it was a hoax with parts from different animals sewn together!
Platypuses can sense the electric fields of their prey using their bills.
They glow blue-green under ultraviolet light!
threats: Habitat loss from dams and water extraction
whatYouCanDo: Support river conservation in Australia
Help reduce water pollution
Learn about this amazing egg-laying mammal

name: Northern Hairy-nosed Wombat
habitat: Semi-arid grasslands and eucalyptus woodlands of Queensland, Australia
description: The Northern Hairy-nosed Wombat is one of the rarest mammals in the world. They are bigger and softer than other wombats, with silky fur and a cute hairy nose. They dig large burrow systems underground where they rest during the hot day.
funFacts: Wombat poop is cube-shaped! They use it to mark their territory without it rolling away.
They can run up to 25 miles per hour in short bursts.
Their backward-facing pouch keeps dirt out when they dig burrows.
whatYouCanDo: Support wombat conservation programs in Australia
Learn about Australia's unique marsupials
Share the story of this rare wombat with others

name: Matschie's Tree Kangaroo
habitat: Mountain cloud forests of the Huon Peninsula in Papua New Guinea
description: Tree Kangaroos are kangaroos that live in trees! They have strong arms for climbing and a long tail for balance. Unlike their ground-dwelling cousins, they can move their back legs independently, which helps them climb branches.
funFacts: Tree kangaroos can jump down from 60 feet high without getting hurt!
They can move their back legs independently, unlike ground kangaroos.
They spend most of their lives in the treetops and only come down occasionally.
whatYouCanDo: Learn about the cloud forests of Papua New Guinea
Support community-based conservation in Papua New Guinea
Tell others about these amazing tree-climbing kangaroos

name: Polar Bear
habitat: Arctic sea ice, coastal areas, and tundra across the Arctic Circle
description: The Polar Bear is the largest land carnivore on Earth. They depend on Arctic sea ice to hunt seals, but climate change is melting the ice faster than ever. Their fur is not actually white; it is transparent and only looks white!
funFacts: Polar bear fur is actually transparent, not white! It just looks white because of how it reflects light.
Under their fur, polar bears have black skin to absorb heat from the sun.
They can smell a seal on the ice from 20 miles away!
threats: Climate change melting Arctic sea ice
Pollution from oil and gas development
Conflict with humans as bears search for food on land
whatYouCanDo: Reduce your carbon footprint to help fight climate change
Turn off lights and save energy at home
Walk or bike instead of driving when possible

name: Arctic Fox
population: Several hundred thousand globally (some populations threatened)
habitat: Arctic tundra and coastal areas across the Northern Hemisphere
description: The Arctic Fox is a small, fluffy fox that can survive in temperatures as cold as minus 70 degrees! Their fur changes color with the seasons, turning white in winter for camouflage in the snow and brown or grey in summer.
funFacts: Arctic foxes can survive temperatures of minus 70 degrees Fahrenheit!
Their fur changes from white in winter to brown in summer for perfect camouflage.
They have the warmest fur of any animal, even warmer than polar bear fur.
threats: Competition from red foxes moving north
Less prey available as ecosystems change
whatYouCanDo: Help fight climate change by saving energy
Learn about Arctic ecosystems and how they are changing
Share facts about Arctic animals with friends

name: Narwhal
habitat: Arctic waters of Canada, Greenland, Norway, and Russia
description: The Narwhal is sometimes called the 'unicorn of the sea' because of the long spiral tusk that sticks out from its head! The tusk is actually a giant tooth that can grow up to 10 feet long. They live in the icy Arctic waters year-round.
funFacts: A narwhal's tusk is actually a tooth that grows in a spiral and can be 10 feet long!
The tusk has millions of nerve endings and can sense changes in water temperature and salt levels.
Narwhals can dive over 5,000 feet deep, one of the deepest-diving mammals!
threats: Increased ship traffic in Arctic waters
whatYouCanDo: Reduce energy use to help fight climate change
Learn about Arctic ocean animals
Support Arctic marine conservation

name: Walrus
habitat: Shallow Arctic seas, ice floes, and rocky coastlines
description: Walruses are huge marine mammals with long tusks, whiskers, and big blubbery bodies. They use their tusks to pull themselves out of the water onto ice and to make holes in ice for breathing. They live in large groups called herds.
funFacts: A walrus's tusks can grow up to 3 feet long and they use them like ice picks!
They have up to 700 whiskers that they use to find shellfish on the dark ocean floor.
Walruses can slow their heartbeat to survive in freezing water.
threats: Loss of sea ice from climate change
Disturbance from ships and industrial activity
whatYouCanDo: Help fight climate change by reducing energy use
Keep oceans clean by reducing plastic waste
Learn about how melting ice affects Arctic animals

name: Snowy Owl
habitat: Arctic tundra across North America, Europe, and Asia
description: The Snowy Owl is a magnificent white owl that lives in the Arctic tundra. Unlike most owls, they hunt during the day because in the Arctic summer, the sun never sets! They became extra famous as Hedwig in the Harry Potter movies.
funFacts: Snowy Owls became famous as Hedwig in the Harry Potter series!
They can eat up to 1,600 lemmings in a single year.
Their feathers are so thick that they are one of the heaviest owl species.
threats: Climate change affecting their tundra habitat
Collisions with vehicles and power lines
whatYouCanDo: Learn about tundra ecosystems
Support Arctic bird conservation
Help fight climate change by saving energy at home

name: Beluga Whale
habitat: Arctic and sub-Arctic coastal waters, rivers, and estuaries
description: Beluga Whales are known as the 'canaries of the sea' because they make so many different sounds including clicks, whistles, and chirps. They are the only whales that can turn their heads from side to side. Their white color helps them hide among ice floes.
funFacts: Belugas can make over 50 different sounds and can even mimic human speech!
They are the only whales that can bend their neck and nod their head.
Baby belugas are born grey or brown and turn white as they grow up.
threats: Noise from ships interfering with their communication
whatYouCanDo: Help keep oceans clean by reducing plastic use
Learn about ocean noise pollution
Support marine mammal protection

name: Blue Whale
habitat: All major oceans worldwide
description: The Blue Whale is the largest animal that has ever lived on Earth, even bigger than the biggest dinosaurs! Their heart alone is the size of a small car, and their tongue weighs as much as an elephant. Despite their enormous size, they eat tiny shrimp-like creatures called krill.
funFacts: A Blue Whale's heart is so big that a small car could fit inside it!
Their tongue weighs as much as an elephant.
A baby blue whale gains about 200 pounds every single day!
threats: Ocean noise pollution interfering with communication
whatYouCanDo: Reduce, reuse, recycle to keep oceans clean
Support marine conservation organizations
Learn about ocean ecosystems and share what you know

name: Vaquita
habitat: Northern Gulf of California, Mexico
description: The Vaquita is the most endangered marine mammal in the world, with possibly fewer than 10 left alive! They are the smallest porpoise in the world and have dark rings around their eyes that make them look like they are wearing makeup.
funFacts: Vaquitas are the smallest porpoises in the world, only about 4 feet long.
They were not even discovered by scientists until 1958!
The dark circles around their eyes and mouth make them look like they have a permanent smile.
threats: Drowning in illegal gillnets set for totoaba fish
whatYouCanDo: Support organizations fighting illegal fishing in Mexico
Never buy products from illegally caught fish
Spread the word about the world's most endangered marine mammal

name: Leatherback Sea Turtle
habitat: Open oceans worldwide, nesting on tropical beaches
description: The Leatherback Sea Turtle is the largest turtle in the world and can weigh over 2,000 pounds! Unlike other sea turtles, they have a soft, leathery shell instead of a hard one. They travel thousands of miles across the ocean every year.
funFacts: Leatherbacks can dive deeper than 4,000 feet, deeper than most submarines!
They travel up to 10,000 miles per year, one of the longest migrations of any animal.
They eat jellyfish and sometimes mistake plastic bags for their food.
threats: Plastic pollution (they eat plastic bags thinking they are jellyfish)
whatYouCanDo: Reduce plastic use, especially plastic bags
Participate in beach cleanups
If you visit a nesting beach, keep lights off and give turtles space

name: Great White Shark
habitat: Coastal and offshore waters of all major oceans
description: The Great White Shark is one of the ocean's top predators and has been around for over 16 million years! Despite their scary reputation, they are actually more threatened by humans than humans are by them. They are important for keeping ocean ecosystems healthy.
funFacts: Great whites can detect a single drop of blood in 25 gallons of water!
They can jump completely out of the water when catching prey, called breaching.
Sharks kill about 5 people per year, while humans kill about 100 million sharks per year.
whatYouCanDo: Never buy shark fin products
Learn the truth about sharks and share it with others
Support shark conservation organizations

name: Scalloped Hammerhead Shark
habitat: Coastal warm waters and open oceans worldwide
description: The Scalloped Hammerhead Shark has one of the most amazing head shapes of any animal! Their wide, hammer-shaped head gives them super-powered senses and helps them find prey hiding under the sand. They swim in large schools of hundreds.
funFacts: Their wide head works like a metal detector, sensing the electric fields of hidden prey!
Baby hammerheads are born with soft, flexible heads so they don't hurt their mothers.
They sometimes swim in schools of over 500 sharks!
threats: Shark finning for shark fin soup
whatYouCanDo: Never eat shark fin soup
Support shark-friendly fishing practices
Learn about why sharks are important for healthy oceans

name: Whale Shark
habitat: Warm tropical and temperate oceans worldwide
description: The Whale Shark is the biggest fish in the entire ocean, growing up to 40 feet long or more! Despite their enormous size, they are gentle giants that eat tiny plankton and small fish by filtering water through their huge mouths.
funFacts: A whale shark's mouth can be up to 5 feet wide, but its throat is only as big as a quarter!
Each whale shark has a unique pattern of spots, like a fingerprint.
They can live to be over 100 years old!
threats: Demand for their fins and meat
whatYouCanDo: Support marine protected areas
Choose sustainably caught seafood
Learn about these gentle giants and share their story

name: Sea Otter
habitat: Coastal waters of the northern Pacific Ocean
description: Sea Otters are adorable marine mammals that float on their backs in the ocean. They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish on their bellies! They have the thickest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
funFacts: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping so they don't drift apart!
They have a special pouch of skin under their arm where they store their favorite rock tool.
Their fur is so thick that their skin never actually gets wet!
whatYouCanDo: Help keep oceans and beaches clean
Support oil spill prevention and cleanup efforts
Reduce, reuse, recycle to protect ocean habitats

name: Green Sea Turtle
habitat: Tropical and subtropical oceans worldwide
description: Green Sea Turtles are named for the green color of their body fat, not their shells! They are the only sea turtles that eat mostly plants as adults, grazing on seagrass and algae like underwater lawn mowers. They can migrate over 1,000 miles to nest.
funFacts: Green sea turtles can hold their breath for up to 5 hours while resting!
They always return to the exact same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
They have been swimming in Earth's oceans for over 100 million years.
threats: Loss of nesting beaches from coastal development
whatYouCanDo: Reduce plastic use to protect sea turtles
Support sea turtle nesting beach protection
Participate in beach cleanups

name: Gharial
habitat: Rivers of northern India and Nepal
description: The Gharial is one of the most unique-looking crocodilians in the world, with an extremely long, thin snout full of sharp teeth. Males have a big bulb on the tip of their nose called a 'ghara.' They are expert fish catchers!
funFacts: Gharials have over 100 sharp teeth perfectly designed for catching slippery fish!
Male gharials have a bulb on their nose that makes a buzzing sound to attract females.
They are one of the longest crocodilians, growing up to 20 feet long.
threats: Loss of river habitat from dams and water extraction
whatYouCanDo: Support river conservation in India
Learn about crocodilians and their role in ecosystems
Help keep waterways clean

name: Przewalski's Horse
habitat: Steppes and grasslands of Mongolia and China
description: Przewalski's Horse is the last truly wild horse species in the world. All other 'wild' horses are actually descendants of domesticated horses that escaped. They went extinct in the wild in the 1960s but have been successfully reintroduced to Mongolia!
funFacts: They are the only truly wild horses left on Earth!
They have 66 chromosomes instead of the 64 that domestic horses have.
Cave paintings of these horses were made by humans over 20,000 years ago!
whatYouCanDo: Learn about Mongolia's amazing grasslands
Support wild horse reintroduction programs
Tell others about the last truly wild horse
